Ken,

   First, I am counting attempting to achieve 80% benefit for 20% 
ef=
fort. And second, I intend to use qadpz to achieve a discrete form 
of para=
llel processing.

   The various experiments and their associated ".ne" par=
ameter files 
reveal a limited range for the various parameters. That being=
 the 
case, could you make any suggestions as to the max ranges which have =

been found to be stable and "play nicely" with neat (i.e. not blow-up 
nea=
t), based upon your experiences?

Thanks,
   Andy


--- In neat@yahoogroups=
.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Andy, the biggest difficu=
lt here will be the CPU time this kind of 
> experiment may require.  In ef=
fect it takes the square of the time 
> it would take to simply run evoluti=
on in a domain with a regular 
> parameter set. That is because e.g. if you=
 had populations of size 
> 100, then it you'd need a meta-population of 10=
0, each of which is 
> an evolution of population 100.
> 
> Perhaps however=
 on some small problems this would still be 
> feasible.  (Certainly with p=
arallel processing it also becomes more 
> feasible)  Yet it's important to=
 remember that it is likely that 
> what you are finding are the right para=
meters for *that* problem, 
> rather than the best ones in general (it's li=
kely there is no 
> such "best"). 
> 
> In any case, if you did run such an=
 experiment, it's a good 
question 
> what the inputs would be.  I would ad=
d to your list inputs that let 
> the network see the current parameter set=
tings, e.g. the current 
> mutation rate, etc.  That way, it can deduce, e.=
g., "hey the slope 
> isn't good and I have a really low mutation rate so m=
aybe I should 
> notch it up a little."  That is, it's useful to know what =
state 
> you're in before you think about changing it.
> 
> With that in mi=
nd, you might consider the outputs being delta 
values 
> rather than absol=
utes.  In other words, they would request 
> a "normalized" change magnitud=
e on their respective parameters.  
> That way the network has (in an abstr=
act sense) an "egocentric" 
> perspective of how it moves through parameter=
 space.  However, if 
> that doesn't work well, you can always try absolute=
s (on a 
> normalized range).  In either case, I'm imagining one output for=
 
> each evolution parameter that the network controls.
> 
> Good luck,
> 
=
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@> wrote:
> >
> > =
   I am currently working on a version of neat to supervise neat, 
> by 
> =
> way of manipulation of the parameters on a generation by 
> generation 
>=
 > basis for the purpose of attempting to accelerate the integral of 
> the=
 
> > fitness of the underlying neat task (UNT). The byproduct would be 
> =
the 
> > evolution of a supervisor genome.
> > 
> >    My current thoughts =
regarding inputs to the supervisor are as 
> > follows:
> > 
> > 1) normali=
zed log of UNT generation #,
> > 2) last UNT generation highest fitness (HF=
),
> > 3) last UNT generation HF accum,
> > 4) # of generations since last =
change of HF of UNT,
> > 5) average of UNT generation HF,
> > 6) slope of a=
verage of UNT generation HF (last 2 points),
> > 7) slope of HF accum (last=
 2 points).
> > 
> >    Does anyone have any thoughts regarding the contemp=
lated 
> inputs, 
> > and/or suggestions for possible other candidate input=
s?
> > 
> >    Thoughtful suggestions are always appreciated!
> > 
> > Than=
ks,
> >    Andy
> >
>
